title: Verticordia patens
text:
Verticordia patens is a <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a> in the myrtle <a href="Family%20%28biology%29">family</a>, <a href="Myrtaceae">Myrtaceae</a> and is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to the <a href="Southwest%20Australia">south-west</a> of <a href="Western%20Australia">Western Australia</a>. It is a shrub with linear, pointed leaves and faintly scented, pale yellow flowers in open heads on the ends of the branches. It is fairly common in a small area south of <a href="Badgingarra%2C%20Western%20Australia">Badgingarra</a>.
Description.
"Verticordia patens" is a slender, woody shrub which grows to a height of between and up to wide. The leaves are linear in shape, semi-circular in cross-section and long with a pointed end.
The flowers are faintly scented and arranged in fairly open, <a href="corymb">corymb</a>-like groups on the ends of the branches on erect stalks long. The <a href="Hypanthium">floral cup</a> is about long, <a href="wikt%3Aglabrous">glabrous</a> and slightly warty. The <a href="sepal">sepal</a>s are spreading, lemon-yellow, long, with between 5 and 7 feathery lobes and two hairy <a href="wikt%3Aappendage">appendage</a>s. The <a href="petal">petal</a>s are erect, pale yellow, about long and egg.shaped with a toothed margin. The <a href="Stigma%20%28botany%29%23Style">style</a> is long, straight and glabrous. Flowering time is from September to November.
Taxonomy and naming.
This species was first formally described by <a href="Alex%20George">Alex George</a> in 1966 and the description was published in "Western Australian Naturalist". He collected the <a href="Type%20%28biology%29">type specimen</a> at <a href="Moore%20River">Moore River</a>. The <a href="Botanical%20name">specific epithet</a> ("patens") is a <a href="Latin">Latin</a> word meaning "open" referring to the open branching habit of this species.
When he reviewed the genus in 1991, George placed this species in subgenus <a href="Verticordia%20subg.%20Chrysoma">"Chrysoma"</a>, section <a href="Verticordia%20sect.%20Chrysorhoe">"Chrysohoe"</a> along with "<a href="Verticordia%20nitens">V. nitens</a>" and "<a href="Verticordia%20nitens">V. nitens</a>".
Distribution and habitat.
This verticordia occurs in a small area between Badgingarra, <a href="Coorow%2C%20Western%20Australia">Coorow</a> and Moore River. It usually grows in sand or gravelly soil, sometimes over <a href="laterite">laterite</a> or <a href="loam">loam</a>, in <a href="heath">heath</a>, <a href="shrubland">shrubland</a> or low <a href="woodland">woodland</a>.
Conservation.
"Verticordia patens" is classified as "not threatened" by the Western Australian Government <a href="Department%20of%20Parks%20and%20Wildlife%20%28Western%20Australia%29">Department of Parks and Wildlife</a>. Although its range is limited, it is fairly common in that area, part of which includes a significant national park.
Use in horticulture.
It possible to propagate "V. patens" from cuttings but the plant has proven difficult to maintain in the garden due to its susceptibility to fungal disease.
